G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: The amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Lynn Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Lynn, Essex County, Massachusetts, and the Property is located in this judicial district.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: As the owner, landlord, and person in control of the Property, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful tenant, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas, including the hallways and smoke detection systems, in a reasonably safe condition. See, e.g., *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–55 (2013) (landowner must act as a reasonable person in maintaining property).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: The excerpt provided is only a concurring paragraph by Justice Kaplan, focused on the treatment of trespassers versus licensees and invitees. It does not mention landlords, tenants, common areas, or specific duties regarding maintenance of hallways or smoke detection systems. While the main Mounsey opinion is known for adopting a general reasonable-care duty to lawful visitors, that broader rule is not evident in the quoted text, so based solely on this excerpt the case does not clearly support the specific landlord–tenant duty proposition cited.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: As the owner, landlord, and person in control of the Property, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful tenant, a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas, including the hallways and smoke detection systems, in a reasonably safe condition. See, e.g., *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–55 (2013) (landowner must act as a reasonable person in maintaining property).
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants and must maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition. While the facts concern a backyard trampoline–pool setup rather than interior common areas or smoke detectors, the case is properly cited for the broader proposition that a landowner must act as a reasonable person in maintaining property for lawful entrants, including tenants.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).” (465 Mass. at 154)

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 239, § 8A, landlords are obligated to maintain residential premises in compliance with the state sanitary code, 105 CMR 410.000, including provisions related to safety equipment.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 239, § 8A, landlords are obligated to maintain residential premises in compliance with the state sanitary code, 105 CMR 410.000, including provisions related to safety equipment.

105 CMR 410.000.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 239, § 8A, landlords are obligated to maintain residential premises in compliance with the state sanitary code, 105 CMR 410.000, including provisions related to safety equipment.

105 CMR 410.482.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.482, and the Massachusetts fire safety requirements, including but not limited to G.L. c. 148, § 26F and applicable building codes (e.g., 780 CMR and incorporated NFPA standards), require functioning smoke detectors in residential buildings to protect occupants from the dangers of fire and smoke.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 26F.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.482, and the Massachusetts fire safety requirements, including but not limited to G.L. c. 148, § 26F and applicable building codes (e.g., 780 CMR and incorporated NFPA standards), require functioning smoke detectors in residential buildings to protect occupants from the dangers of fire and smoke.

780 CMR and incorporated NFPA standards.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.482, and the Massachusetts fire safety requirements, including but not limited to G.L. c. 148, § 26F and applicable building codes (e.g., 780 CMR and incorporated NFPA standards), require functioning smoke detectors in residential buildings to protect occupants from the dangers of fire and smoke.

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: A violation of safety statutes or regulations designed to protect a class of persons that includes the Plaintiff is evidence of negligence. See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990); *Medeiros v. Middlesex Ins. Co.*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 51, 53–54 (1999).
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that violation of G.L. c. 138, § 69 (a safety statute aimed at protecting the public from drunken driving) does not create civil liability by itself, but is “some evidence” of negligence as to the harms the statute is intended to prevent. That is effectively the principle that violation of such a safety statute designed to protect a class including the plaintiff is evidence of negligence, not negligence per se. Thus the case supports the cited proposition, with the caveat that the evidence is not conclusive.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “While a violation of c. 138, § 69, carries criminal penalties, the statute does not expressly or implicitly grant an independent ground for civil liability… It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se… Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent.”

*Medeiros v. Middlesex Ins. Co.*, 48 Mas.raw_text: *Medeiros v. Middlesex Ins. Co.*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 51, 53–54 (1999)
*Medeiros v. Middlesex Ins. Co.*, 48 Mas.proposition: A violation of safety statutes or regulations designed to protect a class of persons that includes the Plaintiff is evidence of negligence. See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990); *Medeiros v. Middlesex Ins. Co.*, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 51, 53–54 (1999).
*Medeiros v. Middlesex Ins. Co.*, 48 Mas.support_reasoning: Nothing in the provided Medeiros opinion discusses violations of safety statutes or regulations, negligence per se, or the evidentiary use of statutory/regulatory violations. The case concerns insurance coverage, negligent misrepresentation by an insurance agent, contract liability, and the preclusive effect of a dismissal with prejudice. It therefore does not establish or affirm the proposition that violation of a safety statute designed to protect a class of persons is evidence of negligence; that principle comes from other cases such as Bennett, not from Medeiros.
*Medeiros v. Middlesex Ins. Co.*, 48 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The record, including the plaintiffs uncontroverted affidavit, clearly reveals policy ambiguity and genuine issues of material fact regarding the respective intentions attributable to the parties at the time the policy was written and the insureds’ reasonable expectations of coverage attendant upon the policy provisions and Drinon’s representations… The existence of substantial factual questions relating directly to the central issue of the parties’ intentions rendered impossible a definitive interpretation of the scope of coverage under the Egan policy… and thus precluded summary judgment with respect to the requested declaratory relief…

*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 4.proposition: Defendant also had a duty under common law to exercise reasonable care in responding to known, reported defects on the premises. See *Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 447 (1979) (landlord liable for failure to remedy known dangerous condition); *Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 833 (1997).
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 4.support_reasoning: Crowell does recognize a common‑law negligence duty of a landlord in areas under the landlord’s control, but it does not impose a duty specifically tied to the landlord’s “responding to known, reported defects.” Instead, it applies a broader duty of reasonable care that includes the obligation to discover and remedy dangerous conditions the landlord should have found by reasonable inspection, even without prior notice from the tenant. The discussion of a statutory notice regime under G.L. c. 186, § 19 is expressly distinguished from the common‑law negligence theory, not made part of it.
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 4.relevant_excerpt: “If the landlord retained control of the porch, he was under a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep it in such condition that others would not be injured… We think the evidence… warranted findings that the tenant suffered physical harm caused by a dangerous condition on the porch, and that ‘the landlord by the exercise of reasonable care could have: (1) discovered the condition and the unreasonable risk involved therein; and (2) made the condition safe.’ Restatement (Second) of Property, Landlord & Tenant § 17.3 (1977).”

*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 833 (1.proposition: Defendant also had a duty under common law to exercise reasonable care in responding to known, reported defects on the premises. See *Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 447 (1979) (landlord liable for failure to remedy known dangerous condition); *Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 833 (1997).
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 833 (1.support_reasoning: Lyon v. Morphew does not recognize a common-law duty on the part of the defendant to exercise reasonable care in responding to known, reported defects on the premises. Instead, the court explicitly holds that there was no common-law duty to provide or maintain fall protection devices on the roof and that, absent such a duty, the employees could not be held individually liable for failing to replace the railing or correct the condition. Thus, citing Lyon for a general common-law duty to remedy known dangerous conditions misstates its holding and purpose.
*Lyon v. Morphew*, 424 Mass. 828, 833 (1.relevant_excerpt: “From the evidence viewed in a light most favorable to the plaintiff, it could be inferred that they played a role in determining whether the hospital should replace the railing or install an alternative safety device; however, they had no common law or statutory duty to do either. … We have never recognized a common law duty of building owners to place or maintain fall protection safety devices on roofs. … Absent a statutory or common law duty, the director and assistant director may not be held individually liable for failing to replace the safety railing prior to the accident.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care owed to a reasonable landlord under the circumstances and constituted negligence. See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 373–74 (2010) (reasonable care standard in premises liability); *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 171 (1980) (landlord has duty to maintain common areas in reasonably safe condition).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos does not decide that this particular defendant was negligent, but it squarely holds that Massachusetts premises liability—including snow and ice cases—is governed by a general duty of reasonable care owed by property owners/landlords to lawful visitors, eliminating special snow-and-ice exceptions. The proposition cites Papadopoulos only for the existence and content of that reasonable care standard in premises liability, which the opinion clearly articulates and applies, so the case is being used accurately as authority for that legal standard.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980)… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 171.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care owed to a reasonable landlord under the circumstances and constituted negligence. See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 373–74 (2010) (reasonable care standard in premises liability); *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 171 (1980) (landlord has duty to maintain common areas in reasonably safe condition).
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 171.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care to avoid subjecting others to unreasonable risk of harm, and applies that standard to a tenant’s guest injured due to a negligently maintained porch railing. It also discusses and endorses the landlord’s duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining common areas, and extends negligence liability beyond common areas to rented premises when the landlord knows or should know of a defect and has a reasonable opportunity to repair it. Thus, it squarely supports the proposition that a landlord owes a reasonable care standard in premises liability and can be negligent when that standard is breached.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 171.relevant_excerpt:
“Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.… Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well.”

“In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control….”

*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84, 88.proposition: Defendant’s violations of G.L. c. 148, § 26F, the State Sanitary Code, and other applicable codes and regulations constitute evidence of negligence and are relevant to establishing breach of duty. See *Bennett*, 408 Mass. at 358; *Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84, 88–89 (1988) (statutory and code violations admissible as evidence of negligence).
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84, 88.support_reasoning: The opinion does not hold that statutory or code violations are admissible as evidence of negligence or relevant to breach of duty. Instead, it expressly discounts the probative value of the expert’s testimony that the elevator violated Massachusetts regulations, notes that no regulation was in evidence, and emphasizes that interpretation of regulations is a question of law for the court. The court ultimately finds no negligence as a matter of law and does not treat any regulatory noncompliance as evidence of negligence, so citing this case for that proposition is inaccurate.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84, 88.relevant_excerpt: “Also, the fact that a particular inspector would not have passed this elevator on account of its ceiling does not permit the conclusion, either alone or in combination with the other evidence in the case, that an ordinarily prudent owner of a building possessing the defendant’s knowledge would have anticipated the decedent’s conduct and guarded against it. Neither is the testimony that the elevator ceiling violated Massachusetts regulations probative. Interpretation of administrative regulations is a matter of law to be decided by the court.… No relevant regulation was placed in evidence.”

*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.raw_text: *Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 523 (1st Cir. 1990)
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: The absence of a functioning smoke detector in the third-floor hallway was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries. See *Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 523 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law on substantial factor causation); *Sahin v. Sahin*, 435 Mass. 396, 402 (2001).
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether the absence of a functioning smoke detector was a substantial factor in causing a plaintiff’s injuries. Jorgensen is an aviation case about reputation damages and contains a general discussion of Massachusetts proximate cause, including the substantial factor concept, but it does not involve smoke detectors, fire injuries, or apply the substantial factor test to such facts. Thus, it cannot be authority for the specific factual-causation proposition stated, only for the abstract definition of substantial factor under Massachusetts law.
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, proximate cause requires a showing by the plaintiff, first, that the loss was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant's negligence, second, that the defendant's negligence was a but-for cause of the loss, and third, that the defendant's negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the loss.”  905 F.2d at 535-36.

*Sahin v. Sahin*, 435 Mass. 396, 402 (20.proposition: The absence of a functioning smoke detector in the third-floor hallway was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries. See *Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 523 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law on substantial factor causation); *Sahin v. Sahin*, 435 Mass. 396, 402 (2001).
*Sahin v. Sahin*, 435 Mass. 396, 402 (20.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns substantial factor causation and smoke detectors, a tort/negligence issue. Sahin v. Sahin is a domestic relations case about post-judgment relief from a divorce decree under Mass. R. Civ. P. 60(b), fraud, and equity; it does not address causation, personal injury, smoke detectors, or substantial factor analysis. Thus, citing Sahin for that causation proposition is inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s holding or reasoning.
*Sahin v. Sahin*, 435 Mass. 396, 402 (20.relevant_excerpt: Rule 60 (b) does not identify the bases for an independent action. This substantive determination is made by recourse to “judicial principles governing untimely requests for equitable relief from fraudulent judgments” that existed prior to the adoption of rule 60 (b). Historically, relief from a valid and final judgment required more than a showing of common-law fraud. See Hazel-Atlas Glass Co. v. Hartford-Empire Co., 322 U.S. 238, 244-245 (1944) (untimely bid for relief justified only where enforcement of judgment would be “manifestly unconscionable”).

*Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.*.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.*.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to maintain functioning smoke detectors and to remedy a known, serious safety hazard. See *Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996) (foreseeability under Massachusetts negligence law).
*Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.*.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.*.support_reasoning: The cited passage indicates the opposite of what the proposition claims. Justice Lynch concurs that the facts would not warrant a jury finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. Thus, the case is being used here to deny foreseeability, not to support that the injuries and damages were a reasonably foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct.
*Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.*.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.proposition: The act of an unknown person removing the battery, under these circumstances, was itself foreseeable and, in any event, Defendant had actual notice of the missing battery and failed to correct the condition.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns foreseeability of an unknown person’s removal of a battery, and the defendant’s actual notice of and failure to correct that specific hazardous condition. Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp. deals with duty and scope of foreseeable risk in the context of a hospital releasing a sedated patient and a police officer later injured in an unrelated collision; it does not involve unknown actors altering a physical condition or a defendant’s notice of a missing component. The case is cited for limits on duty and foreseeability, not for the stated battery-removal proposition.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: “The law does not impose liability for all harm factually caused by tortious conduct. Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct. … While a third party nonpatient directly injured by a medicated patient who drives an automobile from a hospital may be within the scope of foreseeable risk, a police officer injured in an accident in which the patient is not involved is outside that scope.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: Plaintiff incurred medical expenses in the approximate amount of $4,200 and may incur additional medical expenses in the future related to respiratory issues or follow-up care.

*Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Serv. Co..raw_text: *Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Serv. Co.*, 194 Mass. 582, 583–84 (1907)
*Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Serv. Co..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover the reasonable value of her damaged or destroyed property under Massachusetts law. See *Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Serv. Co.*, 194 Mass. 582, 583–84 (1907).
*Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Serv. Co..case_name: Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Service Co.
*Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Serv. Co..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the proper measure of damages for injury to real property, holding that the plaintiff recovers the *difference in fair market value* of the property before and after the injury, not some generalized ‘reasonable value’ of damaged or destroyed property. It discusses cost of restoration only as possible evidence bearing on diminution in value, not as an independent measure. Thus, the case does not stand for the broad proposition that a plaintiff is entitled to recover the reasonable value of damaged or destroyed property under Massachusetts law; it more specifically endorses a diminution-in-market-value measure for this kind of real property damage.
*Hopkins v. American Pneumatic Serv. Co..relevant_excerpt: “The jury were instructed that, if they came to the question of damages, the plaintiffs were entitled to recover the difference between the fair market value of the property before the injury caused by the defendant and its market value after the injury. This is the correct rule in cases of this kind. … The cost of restoration of the property to its former condition does not necessarily furnish a true criterion for determining damages. … In many cases the cost of repairs would be an accurate measure of the damages.”

*Doyle v. Lahey Clinic Hosp., Inc.*, 469.raw_text: *Doyle v. Lahey Clinic Hosp., Inc.*, 469 Mass. 832, 853 (2014)
*Doyle v. Lahey Clinic Hosp., Inc.*, 469.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to compensation for physical pain and mental suffering resulting from Defendant’s negligence. See *Doyle v. Lahey Clinic Hosp., Inc.*, 469 Mass. 832, 853 (2014).
*Doyle v. Lahey Clinic Hosp., Inc.*, 469.case_name: Auto Flat Car Crushers, Inc. v. Hanover Insurance Co.
*Doyle v. Lahey Clinic Hosp., Inc.*, 469.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance coverage and Chapter 93A business dispute focusing on an insurer’s duty to defend and the availability of 93A damages after reimbursement. It does not concern a negligence action, bodily injury, or recovery for physical pain and mental suffering. Nothing in the cited pages (or elsewhere in the excerpt) discusses categories of tort damages available to a plaintiff under Massachusetts negligence law, so the case does not support the proposition claimed.
*Doyle v. Lahey Clinic Hosp., Inc.*, 469.relevant_excerpt: Section 11 bestows a right of action on “[a]ny person who engages in the conduct of any trade or commerce and who suffers any loss of money or property, real or personal,” as a result of the unfair or deceptive act or practice, or unfair method of competition, of another person who engaged in trade or commerce. G. L. c. 93A, § 11, first par. Such monetary or property loss constitutes the “actual damages” to which a prevailing plaintiff is entitled; a plaintiff may recover up to three times that amount upon a finding of a wilful or knowing violation of the statute.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Prejudgment and postjudgment interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Costs of this action, including allowable filing fees and service costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq.;
